docs.title: Home
docs.text: PyMedX is a fork from a archived project called PyMed: gijswobben/pymedx

docs.title: PyMedX - PubMed Access through Python
docs.text: PyMedX is a Python library that provides access to PubMed through the PubMed API.

docs.title: Why this library?
docs.text: The PubMed API is not very well documented and querying it in a performant way is too complicated and time consuming for researchers. This wrapper provides access to the API in a consistent, readable and performant way.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
This library takes care of the following for you:

  • Querying the PubMed database (with the standard PubMed query language)
  • Batching of requests for better performance
  • Parsing and cleaning of the retrieved articles

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
For full (working) examples have a look at the examples/ folder in this repository. In essence you only need to import the PubMed class, instantiate it, and use it to query:

from pymedx import PubMed
pubmed = PubMed(tool="MyTool", email="my@email.address")
results = pubmed.query("Some query", max_results=500)

docs.title: Notes on the API
docs.text:
The original documentation of the PubMed API can be found here: PubMed Central. PubMed Central kindly requests you to:

  • Do not make concurrent requests, even at off-peak times; and
  • Include two parameters that help to identify your service or application to our servers
  • tool should be the name of the application, as a string value with no internal spaces, and
  • email should be the e-mail address of the maintainer of the tool, and should be a valid e-mail address.

docs.title: Notice of Non-Affiliation and Disclaimer
docs.text: The author of this library is not affiliated, associated, authorized, endorsed by, or in any way officially connected with PubMed, or any of its subsidiaries or its affiliates. The official PubMed website can be found at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/.

docs.title: Bug Fixes
docs.text: • Fix initial linter issues and tests (#2) (22a7eb7)

docs.title: Contributing
docs.text:
In order to be able to contribute, it is important that you understand the project layout. This project uses the src layout, which means that the package code is located at ./src/pymedx.

For my information, check the official documentation: https://packaging.python.org/en/latest/discussions/src-layout-vs-flat-layout/

In addition, you should know that to build our package we use Poetry, it's a Python package management tool that simplifies the process of building and publishing Python packages. It allows us to easily manage dependencies, virtual environments and package versions. Poetry also includes features such as dependency resolution, lock files and publishing to PyPI. Overall, Poetry streamlines the process of managing Python packages, making it easier for us to create and share our code with others.

Contributions are welcome, and they are greatly appreciated! Every little bit helps, and credit will always be given.

You can contribute in many ways:

docs.title: Report Bugs
docs.text:
Report bugs at https://github.com/osl-incubator/pymedx/issues.

If you are reporting a bug, please include:

  • Your operating system name and version.
  • Any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.
  • Detailed steps to reproduce the bug.

docs.title: Fix Bugs
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for bugs. Anything tagged with “bug” and “help wanted” is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Implement Features
docs.text: Look through the GitHub issues for features. Anything tagged with “enhancement” and “help wanted” is open to whoever wants to implement it.

docs.title: Write Documentation
docs.text: PyMedX could always use more documentation, whether as part of the official PyMedX docs, in docstrings, or even on the web in blog posts, articles, and such.

docs.title: Submit Feedback
docs.text:
The best way to send feedback is to file an issue at https://github.com/osl-incubator/pymedx/issues.

If you are proposing a feature:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible, to make it easier to implement.
  • Remember that this is a volunteer-driven project, and that contributions are welcome :)

docs.title: Get Started!
docs.text:
Ready to contribute? Here’s how to set up pymedx for local development.

  1. Fork the pymedx repo on GitHub.

  2. Clone your fork locally:

$ git clone git@github.com:your_name_here/pymedx.git
  1. Install your local into a conda environment. Assuming you have conda installed, this is how you set up your fork for local development:
$ cd pymedx/
$ conda env create --file conda/dev.yaml
$ conda activate pymedx
$ poetry install
  1. Create a branch for local development:
$ git checkout -b name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature

Now you can make your changes locally.
  1. When you’re done making changes, check that your changes pass linter and tests:
$ makim tests.linter
$ makim tests.unit
  1. Commit your changes and push your branch to GitHub:
$ git add .
$ git commit -m "Your detailed description of your changes."
$ git push origin name-of-your-bugfix-or-feature
  1. Submit a pull request through the GitHub website.

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
Before you submit a pull request, check that it meets these guidelines:

  1. The pull request should include tests.
  2. If the pull request adds functionality, the docs should be updated. Put your new functionality into a function with a docstring, and add the feature to the list in README.rst.
  3. The pull request should work for Python >= 3.8.1

docs.title: Release
docs.text: This project uses semantic-release in order to cut a new release based on the commit-message.

docs.title: Commit message format
docs.text:
semantic-release uses the commit messages to determine the consumer impact of changes in the codebase. Following formalized conventions for commit messages, semantic-release automatically determines the next semantic version number, generates a changelog and publishes the release.

By default, semantic-release uses Angular Commit Message Conventions. The commit message format can be changed with the preset or config options_ of the @semantic-release/commit-analyzer and @semantic-release/release-notes-generator plugins.

Tools such as commitizen or commitlint can be used to help contributors and enforce valid commit messages.

The table below shows which commit message gets you which release type when semantic-release runs (using the default configuration):

Commit message Release type fix(pencil): stop graphite breaking when pressure is applied Fix Release feat(pencil): add 'graphiteWidth' option Feature Release perf(pencil): remove graphiteWidth option Chore BREAKING CHANGE: The graphiteWidth option has been removed Breaking Release

source: https://github.com/semantic-release/semantic-release/blob/master/README.md#commit-message-format

As this project uses the squash and merge strategy, ensure to apply the commit message format to the PR's title.

docs.title: Stable release
docs.text:
To install PyMedX, run this command in your terminal:

$ pip install pymedx

This is the preferred method to install PyMedX, as it will always install the most recent stable release.

If you don't have pip installed, this Python installation guide can guide you through the process.

docs.title: From sources
docs.text:
The sources for PyMedX can be downloaded from the Github repo.

You can either clone the public repository:

$ git clone https://github.com/osl-incubator/pymedx

Or download the tarball:

$ curl -OJL https://github.com/osl-incubator/pymedx/tarball/main

Once you have a copy of the source, you can install it with:

$ poetry install

docs.title: pymedx
docs.text: PyMedX package.

docs.title: PubMed
docs.text:
Bases: object

Wrapper around the PubMed API.

docs.title: __init__(tool='my_tool', email='my_email@example.com')
docs.text:
Initialization of the object.

Returns:

Type Description - None

docs.title: _exceededRateLimit()
docs.text:
Helper method to check if we've exceeded the rate limit.

Returns:

Type Description - exceeded Bool, Whether or not the rate limit is exceeded.

docs.title: _get(url, parameters, output='json')
docs.text:
Generic helper method that makes a request to PubMed.

Returns:

Type Description - response Dict / str, if the response is valid JSON it will

be parsed before returning, otherwise a string is returend

docs.title: _getArticleIds(query, max_results)
docs.text:
Helper method to retrieve the article IDs for a query.

Returns:

Type Description - article_ids List, article IDs as a list.

docs.title: _getArticles(article_ids)
docs.text:
Helper method that batches a list of article IDs and retrieves the content.

Returns:

Type Description - articles List, article objects.

docs.title: getTotalResultsCount(query)
docs.text:
Helper method that returns the total number of results that match the query.

Returns:

Type Description - total_results_count Int, total number of results for the query in PubMed

docs.title: query(query, max_results=100)
docs.text:
Method that executes a query agains the GraphQL schema, automatically inserting the PubMed data loader.

Returns:

Type Description - result ExecutionResult, GraphQL object that contains the result

in the "data" attribute.

docs.title: get_version()
docs.text: Return the program version.
